{{other people|Robert Brennan}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert Brennan | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1944}} | birth_place = [[Paddy Hill, New York|Paddy Hill]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | education = Seton Hall | occupation = Certified public accountant, stockbroker, racetrack owner, racehorse owner | known_for = | party = | spouse = | children = 3 boys | parents = | relations = | boards = [[First Jersey Securities]], [[Seton Hall University]], [[Garden State Park Racetrack]] }} '''Robert Emmet Brennan''' (born 1944) is an [[United States|America]]n businessman who built the infamous [[penny stock]] brokerage firm, First Jersey Securities. The firm specialized in promoting "[[Pump and dump]]" penny stocks to unsuspecting investors, many of them elderly, who lost their entire investments when the stocks inevitably crashed.
==First Jersey Securities Fraud==
As a result of this penny stock scheme, Brennan became a target of the United States [[Securities and Exchange Commission]]. First Jersey itself went bankrupt in 1987 and Brennan was found guilty of securities fraud in 1994. The US Government ordered him to pay $75 million to settle the fraud claims.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/25/weekinreview/ideas-trends-hubris-and-the-artifice-of-a-dealer.html | work=The New York Times | title=Ideas & Trends; Hubris And the Artifice of A Dealer | first=Matthew | last=Purdy | date=1995-06-25 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
Brennan declared bankruptcy in 1995 but committed another fraud when he did not declare all of his assets to the court. Brennan withheld from the bankruptcy court that he held $500,000 in casino chips that he had purchased (and later cashed out of after his bankruptcy) and $4 million in municipal bonds he kept in his basement. He then directed an associate to liquidate the bonds overseas and invest them in stocks, which netted him $16 million in ill-gotten gains.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/06/sports/sports-of-the-times-greed-and-sheer-gall-catch-up-to-brennan.html | work=The New York Times | title=Sports of The Times; Greed and Sheer Gall Catch Up to Brennan | first=George | last=Vecsey | date=2000-08-06 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/13/nyregion/ex-financier-used-code-names-and-dummy-firms-witness-says.html | work=The New York Times | title=Ex-Financier Used Code Names and Dummy Firms, Witness Says | first=Robert | last=Hanley | date=2001-03-13 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
==Money Laundering==
In 2001 Brennan was found guilty of [[money-laundering]] and bankruptcy fraud and sentenced to a [[prison]] term of nine years and two months. [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/27/nyregion/jail-term-for-former-penny-stock-tycoon.html] On appeal, in 2003 the sentence was upheld. Brennan served part of his sentence at the US Bureau of Prison's [[Fort Dix#Federal Correctional Institution|Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institution]] in Fort Dix, New Jersey. He was released on January 14, 2011 from Fort Dix and was sent to another less harsh prison until July which is when he was released.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.harnessracing.com/news/gspsbobbrennanreleasedfromprison.html | title=GSP's Bob Brennan is released from prison | work=harnessracing.com | date=2011-01-14}}</ref>
==Personal life==
Brennan grew up in [[Newark, New Jersey]], one of nine children. His first wife, Cecelia, was his childhood sweetheart. He attended St Leo's Roman Catholic School in Irvington, and was taught by the School Sisters of Notre Dame, and [[St. Benedict's Preparatory School]] in Newark and in 1973 donated $10 million to the school which allowed it to significantly upgrade its facilities. [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/21/business/us-ruling-may-undercut-brennan-s-other-projects.html] A major benefactor to [[Seton Hall University]], following his conviction the university's Board of Governors had Brennan's name removed from a recreation center on its campus in [[South Orange, New Jersey]]. Brennan is an alumnus of [[Seton Hall University]] and sat on its Board of Regents.<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/sep2002/nf20020920_9297.htm Business Week article 'Seton Hall of Shame']</ref>
Brennan was also a [[Certified Public Accountant]] but his license was revoked as a result of his criminal conviction. {{Citation needed|date=December 2009}}
==Thoroughbred racing== International Thoroughbred Breeders, Inc., a publicly held company founded and chaired by Brennan, financed the reconstruction of [[Garden State Park]] race track in Cherry Hill, New Jersey after it was taken out by a 1977 fire. The grandstand reopened in 1985, closed in 2001, was demolished, and the property redeveloped. Brennan also owned and raced [[Thoroughbred]]s under the name Due Process Stable. The best known of his horses were [[Eclipse Award]] winners [[Deputy Minister (horse)|Deputy Minister]] and his son [[Dehere]], who was bred by Brennan. [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DN&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI|DN&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2A0B810A38D15&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM]
Brennan also built and owned the Due Process Stable Golf Club in [[Colts Neck Township, New Jersey]], where he lived until his arrest in 2001.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE5D91E30F931A35752C1A9669C8B63 "Metro Business Briefing; Ex-financier Indicted Again"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 2, 2000. Accessed November 27, 2007.</ref>

{{Use American English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Ronaldo Mouchawar | image = Ronaldo Mouchawar.jpg | image_size = 180px |birth_place = [[Aleppo]], [[Syria]] | residence = [[Dubai]], [[UAE]] | alma_mater = [[Northeastern University]] | occupation = Founder & CEO of [[Souq.com]] }} '''Ronaldo Mouchawar''' ({{lang-ar|رونالدو مشحور}}), is a [[Syrian people|Syrian]] entrepreneur who is the CEO and co-founder of [[Souq.com]], the largest e-commerce retailer in the [[Arab World]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/en/news/read/2015/the-billion-dollar-start-up-club/articleid/8789 |title=The Billion-Dollar Start-Up Club |publisher=Forbes Middle East |date= |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> He is a veteran of [[Maktoob]], the internet portal purchased by [[Yahoo]] in 2009. In 2005 he launched souq.com.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/294267|title=Making History (Literally): Souq.com CEO Ronaldo Mouchawar|last=Thomas|first=Aby Sam|date=2017-05-14|work=Entrepreneur|access-date=2017-08-17|language=en}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Ronaldo Mouchawar was born in [[Aleppo]], in [[Syria]]. His father was a merchant, and this provided the inspiration for the name of the e-commerce site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/ronaldo-mouchawar-how-i-created-souq-com-545057.html?page=1 |title=Ronaldo Mouchawar: How I created Souq.com |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> Mouchawar is also a former basketball player of the [[Jalaa SC (men's basketball)|Jalaa SC Aleppo]].<ref>[http://b2b-sy.com/news/45543/ استثمارات رجال الأعمال السوريين في الخارج أرقام ضخمة .. ومشاريع كبيرة]</ref>
Mouchawar holds a Master’s degree in digital communications and a Bachelor's Degree in electrical and computer engineering from [[Northeastern University]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Fida Chaaban |url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/250860 |title=Follow The Leader: Ronaldo Mouchawar, Founder And CEO, Souq |publisher=Entrepreneur.com |date=2016-04-17 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> He spent the early years of his career with the Boston engineering firm working in technology and business management, including a role as technical and systems consultant at [[Electronic Data Systems]] (EDS).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://africa-me.com/souq-com-ceo-ronaldo-mouchawar-empowering-the-middle-east-through-e-commerce/ |title=Profile of Souq.com CEO Ronaldo Mouchawar |publisher=Africa-me.com |date=2015-10-30 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
==Career== Mouchawar co-founded Souq.com in 2005 alongside Jabbar, [[Internet Group]]'s Samih Toukan, and Hussam Khoury.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/ronaldo-mouchawar-how-i-created-souq-com-545057.html?tab=Article |title=Ronaldo Mouchawar: How I created Souq.com |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
=== 'White Friday' ===
In 2014, he established the White Friday sales event to coincide with [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] in the US, explaining that a "black" Friday doesn't make cultural sense in the Arab world, since Friday is the traditional day of prayer.<ref>{{cite web|author=Deborah Amos Facebook Twitter |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2014/12/04/368242510/a-syrian-entrepreneur-looks-to-build-the-amazon-of-the-arab-world |title=A Syrian Entrepreneur Looks To Build The Amazon Of The Arab World : Parallels |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> The sale was widely popular as it raised over $275 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wamda.com/2016/02/souq-raises-menas-largest-round-of-275m |title=Souq raises MENA's largest round of $275M |publisher=Wamda.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> In 2015 Souq.com more than doubled its sales during its second White Friday sale, with 13 million visitors and 600,000 items sold during November 25–28 across the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/souq-com-sales-double-during-white-friday--614475.html |title=Souq.com sales ‘double during White Friday’ |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date=2015-12-07 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> Additionally it was involved in the exclusive release of the Huawei Honor 6 launch in Abu Dhabi.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chaaban|first1=Fida|title=Follow The Leader: Ronaldo Mouchawar, Founder And CEO, Souq|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/250860|website=Entrepreneur Middle East}}</ref>
=== Funding and Amazon acquisition ===
In February 2016, Souq.com announced it had received $275m of funding, with a valuation above $1bn, the Arab world's largest ever funding deal, making the e-commerce retailer the region's first [[Unicorn (finance)|unicorn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pr.souq.com/123241-souq-com-raises-more-than-aed-1-billion-usd-275-million-the-largest-e-commerce-funding-in-the-middle-east-history |title=Souq.com raises more than AED 1 Billion (USD 275 million), the largest e-commerce funding in the Middle East history - Souq.com (news) |publisher=Pr.souq.com |date=2016-02-29 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> In March 2017, it was made public that Amazon, the American e-commerce site acquired the brand.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Khalil|first1=Ali|title=Amazon buys Middle East’s biggest online retailer|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/amazon-buys-middle-easts-biggest-online-retailer/|website=Times of Israel|accessdate=20 April 2017}}</ref> The sum of this deal was not initially disclosed, though an Amazon SEC filing later revealed that the total sum paid was $580m in cash.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Khalil|first1=Ali|title=Amazon buys Middle East’s biggest online retailer|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/amazon-buys-middle-easts-biggest-online-retailer/|website=Times of Israel|accessdate=20 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1018724/000101872417000051/amzn-20170331x10q.htm|title=SEC Filing - Amazon.com (Form 10Q; Q1 '17)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.sec.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-17}}</ref>
==Awards== Ronaldo Mouchawar has received several professional awards both in UAE and overseas. *2013: Gulf Business Industry Awards, CEO of the year *2015: Entrepreneur of the Year award

A '''sandwich degree''' is a course specific to the United Kingdom, a four-year [[undergraduate]] course – if it's part of a bachelor's degree – or – if it's part of a master's degree – a five-year [[postgraduate]] course in which students undertake a placement year, or [[internship]] in industry; normally after the second year at university.
==History== The concept was first articulated in a 1945 report by the Ministry of Education which advocated those attending courses at technical colleges would receive a new kind of education in which theoretical studies and industrial training would be interwoven.<ref name=DAvis1979>{{cite paper|title=The council for national academic awards 1964-74: a study of a validating agency|author=Davis, Martin C.|date=1979|url=https://dspace.lboro.ac.uk/dspace-jspui/bitstream/2134/7924/3/Thesis-1979-Davis.pdf|publisher=Loughborough University}}</ref>{{Rp|11}} The term "sandwich" was used in a 1950 National Advisory Council on Education for Industry and Commerce report on possible developments within the further education sector.<ref name=DAvis1979/>{{Rp|13}} During the early 1950s, sandwich course proposals were formulated involving the close association of industry and colleges, encouraging movement of students and researchers between academia and industry.<ref name=DAvis1979/>{{Rp|14-15}} Growth of sandwich courses was encouraged by a Ministry of Education [[white paper]] on Technical Education 1956.<ref name="DAvis1979" />{{Rp|16-17}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://technicaleducationmatters.org/2009/08/20/chapter-12-developments-in-the-1950s-and-1960s/|title=Chapter 12 Developments in the 1950s and 1960s|website=technicaleducationmatters.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref>
The [[Newcastle Polytechnic]] Bachelor of Arts degree in "Design for Industry" starting in 1953 was an early example of this kind, formerly a three-year "Industrial Design" degree. The new course with two additional terms for industrial placements, extended the degree to four years and popularised the term "sandwich course". Alumni include [[Rick Dickinson]] of Sinclair and [[Jony Ive]] of Apple.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2004/apr/04/theobserver.observerbusiness4|title=Design's angel of the North|date=2004-04-03|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polymathperspective.com/?p=3139|title=Rick Dickinson:The Enigma of Design(part 1)|publisher=The Polymath Perspective|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
==Popularity== During 1989 in the United Kingdom, about 20% of the students in higher education were on sandwich courses.<ref>{{citation |journal=Journal of Cooperative Education |volume=26 |issue=2 |year=1990 |title=Sandwich Courses, United Kingdom}}</ref> By 2002 this had dropped to 9.5 percent and by 2010 7.2 percent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/mortarboard/2012/apr/30/students-sandwich-course|title=Why aren't more students doing sandwich courses?|last=Syer|first=Jonathan|date=2012-04-30|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-28}}</ref> Enrollments were growing again by 2014/15.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/why-are-sandwich-courses-seeing-a-resurgence|title=Why are sandwich courses seeing a resurgence?|date=2016-05-01|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-04-30|language=en}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Zippy | logo = Zippy.png | logo_alt = Zippy Logo | industry = [[Retail]] | foundation = 2004 | location = [[Matosinhos]], [[Porto]], [[Portugal]] | homepage = [http://www.zippykidstore.com www.zippykidstore.com] }}
'''Zippy''' is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[brand]] specialized in [[babies]] and [[infants]], that serves [[parents]] and [[children]] from [[birth]] to [[preteen]]. It offers a wide range of [[clothing]] and [[Fashion accessory|accessories]], [[childcare]] products, [[furniture]] and [[toys]], at very affordable [[prices]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sonae.pt/en/brands/zippy/|title = Zippy|date = |accessdate = |website = Sonae's Website|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Integrated in [[Sonae]]’s universe, the brand opened in March 2004 in GaiaShopping, and has 38 [[Retail store|store]]s in [[Portugal]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/zippy-abre-loja-em-setubal-com-conceito-digital_205802.html|title = Zippy abre loja em Setúbal com conceito digital|date = November 12, 2014|accessdate = |website = Diário Económico|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Currently Zippy is present in 20 [[countries]] with over 100 stores.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/comercio/detalhe/sonae_abre_primeira_loja_da_zippy_no_equador.html|title = Sonae abre primeira loja da Zippy no Equador|date = |accessdate = |website = Jornal de Negócios|publisher = |last = March 19, 2015|first = }}</ref>
In November 2014, to celebrate its ten years of existence, Zippy introduced a more [[Modernism|modern]] and [[interactive]] store [[concept]], with [[new technologies]] such as [[digital display]]s and a digital "[[playground]]" where children can [[Play (activity)|play]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.stylus.com/jgqsxb|title = Zippy Interactive Kidswear Flagship|date = December 22, 2014|accessdate = |website = Stylus|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
In addition, Zippy also launched new [[Professional services|services]] for [[families]], as custom childcare [[counseling]] sessions, [[breastfeeding]] pump [[rental]] and replacement trolleys in case of [[failure]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.digidelta.pt/en/noticias/484-netscreen-instala-paineis-na-zippy-e-renova-conceito-de-lojas.html|title = NetScreen install panels at Zippy and renews concept stores|date = |accessdate = |website = Digidelta|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
In 2014 the brand also launched its [[online store]], available in Portugal and [[Spain]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://world.zippykidstore.com/en/world/index.php?id=114&news=88|title = Zippy opens an online store in Portugal and Spain|date = November 14, 2014|accessdate = |website = Zippy's Website|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Innovation == Zippy was the first children's clothing brand in the world to incorporate a colorblind code in its products – ColorADD – allowing an easy and correct identification of colors, in the Spring-Summer 2013 collection.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ColorADD - Color Identification System - a universal and transversal Code that enables colorblind to identify Colors.|url = https://www.changemakers.com/discussions/entries/coloraddcolor-identification-system-universal-and-trans|website = Changemakers|accessdate = 2015-08-17}}</ref>
In June 2015, Zippy launched the first line of children T-shirts with mosquitoes repellent, having already launched a T-shirts line with Ultraviolet Protection Factor.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ZIPPY protege crianças durante 24 horas com novas coleções {{!}} Local.PT|url = http://local.pt/portugal/zippy-protege-criancas-durante-24-horas-com-novas-colecoes/|website = local.pt|accessdate = 2015-08-17|first = Gerson|last = Ingrês|others = (Portuguese)}}</ref> Also in 2015, the brand announced the antibacterial baby line, which inhibits the spread of bacteria.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Zippy launches new and innovative lines|url = http://world.zippykidstore.com/en/world/index.php?id=114&news=106|website = Zippy|accessdate = 2015-08-17|last = Zippy}}</ref>
== Awards == Zippy was elected "Trusted Brand" for the 3rd consecutive year in the children's clothing stores and childcare category.<ref>{{Cite web|title = NetScreen instala paineis na Zippy e renova conceito de lojas|url = http://www.digidelta.pt/en/noticias/484-netscreen-instala-paineis-na-zippy-e-renova-conceito-de-lojas.html|website = www.digidelta.pt|accessdate = 2015-08-17|first = David|last = Pinheiro|others = (Portuguese)}}</ref>
Zippy was also voted “Best Brand” in 2015 in the Fashion category by Marketeer, a Portuguese magazine.<ref>{{Cite web|title = E os vencedores dos Prémios Marketeer 2015 são… {{!}} Marketeer|url = http://marketeer.pt/2015/05/22/e-os-vencedores-dos-premios-marketeer-2015-sao/|website = marketeer.pt|accessdate = 2015-08-17}}</ref>
== Internationalization == The brand’s internationalization started in 2009, in [[Spain]], where Sonae SR began operating outside [[Portugal]]. Today [[Sonae]] continues to make a strong commitment in expanding Zippy.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 10 years of Zippy: a winning story|url = http://www.sonaesharingnews.com/en/n-2/10-years-of-zippy-a-winning-story/|website = |accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref>
In September 2010, Zippy began its expansion in the [[Middle East]] with the opening of stores in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Portugal’s Sonae opens four Saudi stores|url = http://www.arabianbusiness.com/portugal-s-sonae-opens-four-saudi-stores-346433.html|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> In June 2011 was the opening of the first Zippy store in [[Turkey]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae opens Zippy store in Turkey - New Europe|url = http://www.neurope.eu/article/sonae-opens-zippy-store-turkey/|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> In July, the brand arrived in [[Egypt]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = SONAE OPENS FIRST ZIPPY CLOTHING STORE IN EGYPT (Portuguese) - Bloomberg|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=abOy1CRLEqOs|website = www.bloomberg.com|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> In August, Zippy opened the first store in [[Kazakhstan]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = KAZAKHSTAN: Sonae enters market with Zippy store|url = http://www.just-style.com/news/sonae-enters-market-with-zippy-store_id111975.aspx|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref>
In August 2012, Sonae announced the opening of Zippy stores in [[Lebanon]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae abre lojas Zippy no Líbano|url = http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/empresas/interior.aspx?content_id=3868054|website = Dinheiro Vivo|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref> In October, was the announcement of Zippy's entry in [[Azerbaijan]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae anuncia entrada da Zippy no Azerbaijão|url = http://www.publico.pt/economia/noticia/sonae-anuncia-entrada-da-zippy-no-arzebeijao-1568460|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref> and [[Dominican Republic]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae (Portugal) Opens First Store in Latin America - 17 Oct 2012|url = http://www.worldfranchiseassociates.com/franchise-news-article.php?nid=1760|website = www.worldfranchiseassociates.com|accessdate = 2015-08-18|first = Jake|last = Kidde-Hansen}}</ref> In November, Sonae opened the first two Zippy stores in [[Venezuela]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Zippy desembarca na Venezuela|url = http://www.hipersuper.pt/2012/11/15/zippy-desembarca-na-venezuela/|website = Hipersuper|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref>
In March 2013, Sonae exported Zippy for the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] market, extending its presence to [[North Africa]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae opens Zippy store in Morocco|url = http://www.portugalindustry.com/en/new/article/sonae-abre-loja-zippy-em-marrocos-132.html|website = www.portugalindustry.com|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> In September 2013, the first Zippy store opened in [[Jordan]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae Opens Zippy Store in Jordan - SeeNews Portugal {{!}} HighBeam Research|url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-344353601.html|website = www.highbeam.com|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> and, in October, in [[Qatar]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae abre primeira loja Zippy no Qatar|url = http://www.dinheirovivo.pt/empresas/interior.aspx?content_id=3761523|website = Dinheiro Vivo|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref> In 2013 Zippy also started the wholesale channel which currently has over 175 retail outlets worldwide.
In the first quarter of 2014 the brand arrived in [[Armenia]] and [[Kuwait]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae leva Zippy para Arménia, Kuwait e Iraque|url = https://economico.sapo.pt/noticias/sonae-leva-zippy-para-armenia-kuwait-e-iraque_181837.html|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref> In the third quarter of 2014, Zippy expanded its activity in [[Latin America]] with the opening of the first store in [[Chile]] and opened its first store in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], strengthening its presence in the [[Caucasus]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Zippy expands to Chile and Georgia|url = http://world.zippykidstore.com/en/world/index.php?id=114&news=92|website = Zippy|accessdate = 2015-08-18|last = Zippy}}</ref>
In March 2015, Sonae opened the first Zippy store in [[Ecuador]] under the expansion plan in Latin America.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae abre primeira loja da Zippy no Equador|url = https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/empresas/comercio/detalhe/sonae_abre_primeira_loja_da_zippy_no_equador.html|accessdate = 2015-08-18|language = Portuguese}}</ref> In May, Zippy opened its first store in [[Iraq]] ([[Kurdistan]]), expanding the brand's presence in the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sonae enters Kurdistan with ZIPPY - AMEInfo|url = http://ameinfo.com/luxury-lifestyle/lifestyle/fashion/sonae-enters-kurdistan-with-zippy/|accessdate = 2015-08-18}}</ref> In September, the brand announced the entry into four new countries of [[Central America]]: [[El Salvador]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Nicaragua]] and [[Guatemala]].
